entry.title: Re: How to add a new admin task to the Manage My Timeshee...
entry.content:
Dear Customer, 

 

In order to create a new administrative timesheet task please see the following SAP Help Documentation Manage Your Tasks: "Non-Project Related Task Types: You can define task types that do not refer to a specific project like administration tasks or training, in your configuration environment in activity SSCUI 101864 - Specify Task Types, Components, and Levels. You can disable a task type for either internal employees or contingent workers by changing the values in the Task Type Relevance. If a configuration expert disables a task type for internal employees or contingent workers, further modifications cannot be made to the existing data in the timesheet for that task type. Timesheets for such task types can be made only if the task types are once again made available to internal employees or contingent workers.".

 

Many thanks,

entry.title: Re: project valuation class does not work
entry.content:
Hi friend,
Actually, the issue is that the system did not recognize the project-specific valuation class (QKLAS) during MIGO because the valuation type was not properly determined or assigned for the WBS element. You must follow below mentioned points to investigate why it's not determined.

1. Valuation Type Determination
SAP uses the valuation type to differentiate between standard and project valuation classes. If the valuation type is not explicitly maintained or determined during the PO or GR process, the system defaults to the standard valuation class (BKLAS). Please check the valuation type linked to the WBS element in the project definition? If not, the system won‚Äôt switch to QKLAS.

2. Split Valuation Configuration
For project valuation to work, the material must be set up for split valuation. Look into the material master, is split valuation active? Is the valuation category (e.g., ‚ÄòProject‚Äô) assigned? If split valuation isn‚Äôt active, SAP cannot differentiate between standard and project stock.

3. Valuation Class Mapping in OBYC
OBYC-BSX must have separate accounts for each valuation class. Are both BKLAS and QKLAS mapped correctly in OBYC under BSX? If QKLAS is missing or misconfigured, the system may default to BKLAS.

4. Account Assignment Category Q Behavior
When using account assignment category Q (project), SAP expects a WBS element with valuated stock. Is the WBS element flagged for valuated stock in the project system? If not, SAP treats it as non-valuated and uses standard valuation.

5. PO and GR Settings
During PO creation, the valuation type should be selectable or defaulted based on the WBS. Was the valuation type field visible and filled in ME21N? If not, it may need to be enabled via configuration. During MIGO, if the valuation type is not editable or defaulted incorrectly, the GR will post to the wrong account.

Following are my recomendations mentioned below.
Enable split valuation for the material and assign valuation category.
Assign valuation type to WBS element in the project definition.
Ensure OBYC-BSX has correct GL accounts for both BKLAS and QKLAS.
Check PO and GR screens to ensure valuation type is visible and correctly defaulted.
Test with a new PO after correcting the above to confirm correct account posting.

Hope your issue can be fixed with above actions.

entry.title: Re: eDocument SII ‚Äì Canceled invoice before submission does not generate ‚Äúaccepted‚Äù status
entry.content:
Good day!

Dear customer, to answer your question, I will need some clarifications.

Regular submission process (let's take 1 document for example) is the following:

  1. You create an Accounting document (using FB01, for example)
  2. You run a eDoc creation report ESSII_EDOCCREATE - Create eDocuments for SII (Spain). Spain SII eDocument is created and is visible in eDocument Cockpit
  3. You run a eDoc List creation report ESSII_EDOCLIST - Create eDoc Lists for SII (Spain). Spain SII List eDocument is created and is visible in eDocument Cockpit.
  4. You submit this List eDocument to Tax Authorities and recieve their response (Accepted or Rejected). Both List and individual eDocuments statuses are updated.

When you describe your situation, what do you cancel? Individual eDocument or actual SAP Accounting documents? And when does that happen, after the individual eDocument is created or after List is created?

entry.title: SAP for Me for Partners - Recent Enhancements - November 2025
entry.content:
Dear Partners,

We are excited to announce the release of new features in the Customer Success dashboard in SAP for Me.

Projects Tab:

Global Project View for Partner Groups

Partners who are part if a Partner Grouping Agreement (PGA) can have visibility on all projects across the partner group in the Customer Cloud Projects card. This supports partners who are involved in multi-county implementations to have full transparency on the project delivery across countries. Partner group-level visibility provides partners with a comprehensive view of all projects across their affiliated entities, reducing fragmentation and improving oversight.

To access this view, select the ‚ÄúGlobal View‚Äù

Clean Core Quality Gate Status

Partners can now have visibility to the status of customer‚Äôs Clean Core Quality Gate status for S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition projects via the Customer Cloud Projects card. Clean Core Quality Gates are checkpoints at the end of Prepare (QG1), Explore (QG2), Realize (QG3) and the beginning of Run (QG5), designed to ensure that project‚Äôs clean core principles and project tasks adhere to best practices and quality standards.  The complete status indicates the Q-gate is completed in Cloud ALM, clean core report is generated via CQC service and delivered to customer in their Cloud ALM instance.  All QGs need to be completed for new implementation; QG5 is required for Lift & Shift.Refer to this guide (link) to learn more about Clean Core Projects.

 

Project Manager Maintenance

Project managers are crucial for successful customer projects. We‚Äôve added a feature in SAP for Me to let partner search and assign a user as project manager when they register a new project.  This information allows closer alignment between the Partners and SAP teams.  The Project Manager contact is also visible on the Customer Cloud Projects Card.

Renewals Tab:

New Renewal Forecast card

We have introduced a new Renewal Forecast card to support partners with their renewals and churn management. In this new card, partners have visibility to renewal opportunities with renewal date within the current quarter and the next four quarters. Partners can switch views to identify renewal opportunities with missing forecast and renewal opportunities with less than 50% probability. Partners can also easily navigate to the Deal Manager from the card to update the opportunities.

View Upcoming Renewals for the current quarter and the next 4 quarters:

 

View Upcoming Renewals for the current quarter and the next quarter:

View Renewals with Forecast Missing:

Renewals with less than 50% Probability:

If you would like to suggest a new feature for SAP for Me, please access here. Your feedback matters and supports to shape the roadmap for SAP for Me for Partner.

entry.title: Re: Recurring Inspection Lot error in SAP QM
entry.content:
Hi,
What I understand that the stock is not moving to Quality Inspection and the missing Inspection Lot Stock tab in QA07 are likely due to configuration or master data issues‚Äîespecially with inspection type 09 and batch settings.

Stock Not moving
Inspection Lot Creation Timing
In QA07, recurring inspection lots are created based on the next inspection date and the lead time. If the batch expiration or next inspection date is not within the opening period defined in QA07, the lot won't be created.

Inspection Type 09 Configuration
Ensure that inspection type 09 is activated in the material master under the QM view. The control indicator ‚ÄúStock transfer at inspection lot creation‚Äù must be set to move stock from unrestricted to quality inspection.

Batch Master Data
The batch must have a valid next inspection date and shelf life data maintained in the material master (Plant Data/Storage 1 view). If these are missing or incorrect, the system won‚Äôt trigger the inspection lot or stock movement.

QA07 Parameters
In QA07, check the parameter ‚ÄúTransfer to inspection stock‚Äù: If set to ‚ÄúAt inspection date,‚Äù stock won‚Äôt move until that date. If set to ‚ÄúAt lot creation,‚Äù stock should move immediately‚Äîmake sure this is selected.


Stock tab missing in QA07
No Stock Posted to the Lot
If no stock was moved to Quality Inspection, the tab won‚Äôt appear because there‚Äôs nothing to post or decide on.

Inspection Lot Origin
For recurring inspections (origin 09), if the stock isn‚Äôt batch-managed or the lot isn‚Äôt linked to a batch with stock, the tab may not be relevant.

Lot Status
Check the status of the inspection lot in QA03. If it‚Äôs not ‚ÄúREL‚Äù (Released) or doesn‚Äôt have stock assigned, the tab won‚Äôt show.

Hope you can find the reason for both of the issues. if fixed please confirm.

entry.title: Re: Activity Areas in Storage Bin
entry.content:
@Charisma_fitra 

What you need to check

Define the Activity Areas and Activities
In EWM you need to define the ‚ÄúActivity Area‚Äù master data (e.g., for Put‚Äêaway, Picking, Inventory etc) and link it to activities.

Assign the Storage Type (and/or Storage Bin as applicable) to the Activity Area
The key step: assign your storage type (or bin) to the activity area via the customizing ‚ÄúAssign Storage Bins to Activity Areas‚Äù. 

Go to customizing Assign Storage Bins to Activity Areas, assign Storage type to Activity Area.

If your storage type is new and no assignment exists, then the bins in that storage type won‚Äôt show up under any Activity Area.

Define Sort Sequence for Activity Area
After assignment, you also need to define a sort sequence for the activity area (so the system knows how to group/sort bins). 

Go to customizing ‚ÄòDefine Sort Sequence for Activity Area‚Äô, assign storage type to activity area.

Perform Bin Sorting / Create Sorting Records
Once configuration is done, you should run the bin‚Äêsorting (transaction /SCWM/SBST in embedded EWM) to create internal links between bins and activity areas. 

Check in the ‚ÄúDisplay Storage Bin‚Äù App
In the app (e.g. Display Storage Bin /SCWM/LS03) under the Activity Areas tab you should now see the related activity areas for the storage bin. 

Go to APP ‚ÄòDisplay Storage Bin‚Äô ‚Ä¶ Activity Area tab to verify the result.

entry.title: Re: Report related to stock retained period.
entry.content:
Good day @yKim

Thank you for your question.

You can consult the following references for further details.

Batch Management, Material Documents Overview & Batch Information Cockpit.

In summary, the public cloud does not provide standard field that directly displays the ‚Äúdays since last goods receipt‚Äù. However, the system provides you supported options such as:

  • Making use of the Manage Batch Information Cockpit app. This enables you review the last goods receipt date for each batch.
  • The ‚ÄúMaterials Overview‚Äù app helps you use the movement type 101 to track GR posting.
  • You can also make use Custom Analytical Query to create a calculated field to enable you dynamically display elapsed days.
  • Finally, the Shelf-Life Management option enables the use of expiration tracking for time-sensitive materials.

I recommend the clean-core approach where you build a Custom Analytical Query. You can use I_MaterialDocumentItem or I_Batch as your data source and add a calculated field for ‚ÄúDays Since GR‚Äù. This will ensure you comply with public cloud extensibility standards.

 

Below is a guidance.

In your Tenant, search for Batch Information Cockpit app.

Filter for your target Material, relevant batch number. Select the batch details view and confirm last goods receipt date field. Save and preview the results. You will see a calculated ‚ÄúDays Since GR‚Äù column.

You can optionally use Custom Analytical Query to add DaysSinceGR= CurrentDate-LastGoodsReceiptDate as a formular.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: SAP EWM: Staging for production - /SCWM/STAGE - Sched...
entry.content:
@sap_enthusiastic 

Please check the following notes those might be helpful:

  • SAP Note 2022603 - Production staging in EWM: "No staging proposal possible for given selection criteria"
  • SAP Note 2100035 - Explanation on staging methods in EWM

Maybe those checks will help you:

1. Verify PMR Generation

In transaction /SCWM/PMR:

Check that your PMR contains components with requirement quantities > 0.

Make sure the ‚ÄúStaging indicator‚Äù and ‚ÄúSupply area‚Äù are correctly transferred from ERP.

The PMR should have item type PPSC or PPPI (not PPSM), depending on configuration.

If the quantities are zero or ‚Äústaging indicator‚Äù is missing -> staging will be skipped.

2. Confirm Staging Method Configuration

You used staging method 3 (Release Order Parts).

Check in /SCWM/PSASTAGE (Production Supply Area Staging Config):

Warehouse Number / Production Supply Area  matches your input.

Staging Method = 3

Bin Determination and Destination PSA Bin are correctly maintained.

Storage type search sequence for staging exists.

If this config is missing -> EWM finds no destination -> ‚Äúno staging proposal possible‚Äù.

3. Check Component Availability

In /SCWM/MON:

Verify that the materials exist in the same warehouse number, same stock type, and same owner as the PMR.

If HU-managed: confirm HUs are in a pickable bin (not blocked, not GR zone).

If batch-managed: check that batch numbers are identical to those in the PMR.

4. Time Window Parameters

In /SCWM/STAGE, you define a time period for requirement start:

If the PMR requirements fall outside that time window, no quantities are proposed.

Try:

Switch ‚ÄúTest Mode‚Äù off.  Leave ‚ÄúNumber of Hours‚Äù empty or set a larger window (e.g., 9999). Execute again. This ensures the system considers all open requirements.

entry.title: Re: Marketplace App Deployment & Lifecycle Management Usi...
entry.content: For deploying and managing marketplace apps efficiently within the SAP ecosystem, I recommend a DevOps workflow centered around SAP Continuous Integration and Delivery (CI/CD), SAP Cloud Transport Management, and Git-based version control. By automating build, test, and release pipelines, teams can ensure consistent delivery while reducing deployment risks. For lifecycle management, features like automated regression testing, blue-green deployments, and rollback mechanisms help maintain uptime and stability during updates. Security and compliance checks should be integrated early via policy-based validation and API security monitoring. Overall, leveraging SAP‚Äôs DevOps toolchain enables faster development iterations, better scalability, and proactive performance optimization ‚Äî especially critical for marketplace apps that require frequent enhancements and seamless user experience.

entry.title: Exception Handling in SAP BTP Integration Sutie using AI Utility - Part 1
entry.content:
Exception handling in SAP BTP Integration Suite with AI Utility  - Part 1 

Hello!

I spent a lot of time fixing failed integraitons in SAP BTP. the messages were confusing and the business team had no idea what to do next. To help everyone, I built as simple setup that keeps the main business flow running , writes clear error messages and tells the right people what happened. This is the first part of the story. 

What you will learn here 
1. The difference between synchronous and asynchronous error handling 
2. How to finish the main work even when an error appears
3. How I used Google Gemini to rewrite technical errors in plain words
4. How ServiceNow and Loggly receive alerts from the flow 
5. Tips you can reuse in your own projects. 

Synchronous vs Asynchronous - Picking the Right path

Before you build, check how your sender and receiver expect to talk to each other

Synchronous integrations 
1. Example adapters: IDoc or HTTP on the sender , SFTP on the receiver 
2. Goal : Deliver the main message even if the error handling part fails 
3. Helpful tool : Escalation End events in the exception subprocess. They let the utility work fail without stopping the main branch. 

Example: An HTTP flow checks connectivity, write sthe file to SFTP, and only then triggers the error utility. If the utility fails, the Esclation End hands control back to the main path so the main message still succeds

Asynchronous integrations 
1. Same adapters, but the sender does not wait for a quick reply
2. Message move to their own schedule , so you can leave our Esclations Ends. 
3. Use JMS to butter and retry without blocking the main process

Why it works : This style handles more volume , keeps parts seperate and limits the blast radius when something fails. 

Two Flows working together 



I split the solution into two parts so each one can stay simple. 

Main Integration flow : 
1. Receives HTTP calls from other systesm
2. Checks services like loggly or ServiceNow to make sure they are alive
3. Saves good messages to SFTP
4. Forwards error details to the helper flow
5. Finishes even if the helper runs into trouble

GenAI utility flow
1. Picks up the error details 
2. Calls Google Gemini to explain the error in plain English
3. Converts the result into a standard XML format 
4. Sends alerts out to ServiceNow and Loggly. 

Why this setup helps
1. business processing keeps working even when utilities fail 
2. People get error summaries they can understand 
3. Alerts each several teams at once
4. Flows can run in parallel without slowing down
5. Each flow is eassier to change th e rest

Coming Up Next

Part 2 will show : 
1. How to build the main flow step by step 
2. Groovy code that talks to Gemini
3. ServiceNow and Loggly configurations
4. Testing ideas and quick fixes. 
5. Lessons from real project work. 

Stay tuned for the next part.

entry.title: Is It Time to Bring AI Workflows Into SAP Automation?
entry.content:
I‚Äôve been experimenting lately with ways to bring more autonomy into SAP workflows. Most automation setups still rely on rules or triggers, they do what they‚Äôre told, but they don‚Äôt adapt when data or processes change.

What‚Äôs been fascinating is how much potential there is in combining SAP process automation with AI-driven decision logic. Imagine workflows that can detect anomalies in purchase orders, reroute approvals based on context, or sync data intelligently with non-SAP systems without manual rules.

The challenge I keep running into is how to design these ‚ÄúAI-aware‚Äù workflows without adding too much complexity or breaking governance.

So I‚Äôm curious has anyone here tried integrating AI-driven workflows with SAP? Are you doing it through BTP, Integration Suite, or experimenting with other tools or APIs? What‚Äôs been working for you (and what hasn‚Äôt)?

entry.title: Highlights from the Community Booth at the SAP Transformation Excellence Summit 2025 in the Hague
entry.content:
Last week we had the pleasure of connecting with so many of our community members at the SAP Transformation Excellence Summit 2025 in the Hague. What an inspiring few days it was, full of energy, ideas, and meaningful conversations about the future of business transformation. 

Outside the event venue - World Forum, The Hague, Netherlands

This year‚Äôs event took place at the World Forum, an iconic venue that has hosted many global discussions about change and progress. It was the perfect setting for exploring the transformations shaping our business world today. 

Our theme this year, ‚ÄúPower Up,‚Äù focused on how SAP‚Äôs integrated toolchain helps organizations accelerate transformation across processes, people, and technology. Many of the discussions at the booth centered around how SAP Signavio, SAP LeanIX, and WalkMe‚Ñ¢ work together to guide our customers in building capabilities that transform business across applications, processes, people, and data. 

 At the Community Booth, we had the opportunity to meet many of our community members face to face: customers, partners, and practitioners who bring our digital communities to life every day. Thank you to everyone who stopped by to share your stories, ask questions, and exchange insights. Your passion for collaboration and continuous learning is what makes our community thrive. (Sharing some pictures below from the booth with some of our attendees & community members.) 

  

For those who‚Äôd like to keep the momentum going, here are a few ways to stay connected: 

  • Engage with practitioners and enterprise architects in the SAP LeanIX Community to explore modernization and architecture best practices. 
  • Visit the SAP Signavio Community topic page and join us for the upcoming SAP Signavio Community expert session ‚ÄúHow to Establish a Business Process Office to Unleash Your Business Transformation‚Äù on November 19. Register here. 
  • Join/start a discussion in the Business Transformation Group and exchange ideas with peers across industries. 
  • Connect with the Business Transformation Network ‚Äì a trusted global network where companies from different industries and countries exchange learnings, challenges, and best practices. In 2024, the Network hosted more than 330 peer-to-peer exchange sessions and over 20 networking events both virtually and onsite. Topics include SAP‚Äôs own transformation journey from strategy to execution, as well as value management, finance transformation, business process management, enterprise architecture, and change management. To learn more or to get involved, contact transformation@sap.com 

 Lastly, I just want to say a big thank-you to our community members here who joined us in The Hague and contributed to making #SAPTES2025 such a big success. Your engagement, insights, and collaboration continue to power up our global SAP Community. (For those who couldn‚Äôt attend but are interested in the keynotes and sessions presented at the event, I‚Äôm happy to share the event recordings once we have them ready.) 

Please also feel free to share your feedback with us about #SAPTES2025, we would love to know ‚Äì what did you learn, like or enjoy at the event? What would you like to have at the next event? 

We look forward to seeing even more of you at future events, both online and in person. Let‚Äôs keep building the connections that drive transformation forward and keep powering up together. 

SAP BTM Community team

entry.title: SII tip for Spain #5C: SII Adjustments for Canary Islands October 2025 - <BienInversion> and "AJ"
entry.content:
As mentioned in the publication SII tip for Spain #5: SII Adjustments for Canary Islands October 2025, the Canary Islands Tax Agency published the Order of July 10, 2025 modifying Order of 11 October 2018  containing a set of changes in the Canary Islands SII format. In the Annex of this Order, the technical specifications are detailed. In that publication, the new regimes and the AIEM adjustment were mentioned.

In that earlier post, we covered the new regimes and the AIEM adjustment.
In this second part, we focus on two additional changes introduced by the Tax Agency:

Key Enhancements for SAP Customers

  1. Capital Goods Identification
    SAP customers operating in the Canary Islands can now identify incoming invoices related to capital goods (Bienes de inversi√≥n).
  2. Adjustment Document Type ‚ÄúAJ‚Äù
    For Travel Agencies (REAV) and Used Goods Schema (REBU), it is now possible to record adjustments using a new document type: AJ.

 

 

 

Capital Goods

Similar to SII-Spain, it is possible to mark certain tax codes as "Capital Goods" relevant.

Configuration path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> Cross-Application Components -> General Application Functions -> eDocument -> Country/Region-Specific Settings -> Spain -> Settings for Electronic IGIC Register Books With SII -> Assign Additional Attributes to Input Tax Codes for IGIC (SSCUI 107267)

In this customizing activity, you can select "Capital Goods" in the "Attributes" column.

When a tax code is marked as Capital Goods, invoices using this tax code will populate the XML tag:

<BienInversion>S</BienInversion>

Adjustment documents (REBU and REAV)

The special VAT schemas REBU (used goods) or REAV (travel agencies) calculate IGIC and tax base amounts based on estimated profit margins for the invoicing period. At year-end, margins are recalculated, which may require adjustments.

(*) This calculation is not part of the SAP standard.

Once the new margin is calculated, adjustments to IGIC and tax base amounts (positive or negative) can be reported to the Tax Agency using the new document type ‚ÄúAJ‚Äù.

Configuration Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> Cross-Application Components -> General Application Functions -> eDocument -> Country/Region-Specific Settings -> Spain -> Settings for Electronic IGIC Register Books With SII -> Assign SII Attributes to Document Types for IGIC (SSCUI 102992). Mark the relevant accounting document type as "AJ".

 

The IGIC adjustment will be reported as follows:

 

Validation Rules:

  • Fields not reported in the XML message:
    • <FechaOperacion> (Tax fulfillment)
    • Block <Contraparte> (receiver)
  • Mandatory fields:
    • <TipoImpositivo> 
    • <BaseImponible>
    • <CuotaRepercutida>
  • Fixed fields:
    • <TipoFactura> is "AJ"
    • <ClaveRegimenEspecialOTrascendencia> must be either ‚Äú03‚Äù (REBU) or ‚Äú05‚Äù (REAV)
    • <TipoDesglose> must contain only <DesgloseFactura>
    • <TipoNoExenta> = ‚ÄúS1‚Äù 

 

 

 

Disclaimer

This blog post is intended for informational purposes only and reflects a simplified configuration approach based on current legal and system understanding. It does not constitute legal or implementation advice. SAP system behavior may vary depending on version, scope, and customer-specific settings. For full compliance and implementation support, please consult your SAP implementation partner or legal advisor.

 

Related links

In case of additional questions, you can refer to the official SAP documentation:

  • Electronic Tax Register Books with SII in S/4HANA Public Cloud
  • Electronic Tax Register Books with SII in S/4HANA Private Cloud
  • Electronic Tax Register Books with SII in ERP

Other SII tips and community discussions:

  • Spain ‚Äì SAP Document and Reporting Compliance ‚Üí Related Links ‚Üí Community Section

entry.title: Re: SAP Integration Content API - Is it possible to view...
entry.content:
That‚Äôs a great question and a pretty common challenge when documenting complex CPI landscapes. Unfortunately, the Integration Content API doesn‚Äôt expose process direct endpoint values directly, since those are handled at design-time within the artifact and not stored as runtime metadata.

One workaround I‚Äôve seen is exporting the integration packages (via Design APIs or manual export) and parsing the *.iflow descriptor files. You can extract the process direct adapter configuration XML and map endpoint names to flows programmatically. It‚Äôs not elegant, but it gives a full inventory when you need to visualize inter-flow dependencies.

If your goal is to maintain an integration landscape view, you might also consider automating metadata extraction periodically to track changes in endpoints, it helps a lot when new iflows are deployed or versions change.

Would be interested to hear if anyone‚Äôs found a more direct API-based approach recently.

entry.title: Transitioning from Underwriting to Operational Risk Management
entry.content:
Hello SAP Signavio Community,

Hello Everyone,

I‚Äôm transitioning from a Life Insurance Underwriting background into Operational Risk Management, where I use process analysis and simulation to uncover potential operational inefficiencies and risks.

Drawing on my industry experience, I‚Äôm running a personal BPMN project on a fictional but representative company, Nova Life Assurance Ltd  Using SAP Signavio, I‚Äôm mapping key processes, simulating bottlenecks, identifying Key Risk Indicators (KRIs), and proposing TO-BE improvements.

I need feedback on how to improve my BPMN diagram before simulating the process and analysing the outcome. The link to my BPMN Files is attached below.

Onboarding Process - Tied Agent 

Onboarding Process - Independent Agent 

Case Scenario 

 

I will start with Sales & Distribution Processes
Note:

Distribution is done through these channels:

  • Tied Agents ‚Äì Full-time agents serving retail clients (60% of business)

  • Independent Agents ‚Äì Freelance producers on commission

  • Bancassurance Partners ‚Äì Bank officers cross-selling life policies

  • Brokerage & Corporate Sales ‚Äì Handling institutional clients

It‚Äôs led by the Head of Sales & Distribution, with support from the Retail Team, Sales Administration, and Sales Operations units.

I‚Äôve modelled  two onboarding workflows:

  1. Tied Agent Onboarding
    Supervisors recruit, screen, and forward qualified candidates to the Sales Administrator, who manages regulatory licensing with the NIC, creates agent codes, and distributes contracts.
  2. Independent Agent Onboarding
    The Sales Administrator maintains a market database, shortlists agents on request, seeks approval from the Head of Sales, negotiates terms, and activates approved agents after contract signing.

    Next Steps:

    Both workflows seem to be manual and sequential, exposing the company to potential delays. My next phase involves:

    • Simulating the processes in Signavio to measure cycle time

    • Identifying KRIs linked to operational inefficiency

    • Designing TO-BE workflows with automation and standardised approvals

entry.title: Re: Wireshark with SAP Dissectors for Ubuntu and macOS
entry.content:
So got this working with Ubuntu 22.04 arm64 with Gnome Desktop installed (see the above blog for how to set up such a distro, if you are not experienced in Ubuntu installation - from e.g. https://ubuntu.com/download/server/arm you can go to "Alternative and previous releases" to find the 22.04 variants).

But don't bother installing Wireshark just yet.

[

But if you already have Wireshark PPA and from it a Wireshark app: we need to remove Wireshark and remove the PPA. Maybe PPA first:

sudo add-apt-repository --remove ppa:wireshark-dev/stable -y

sudo apt update

Then get rid of Wireshark app itself:

sudo apt remove --purge wireshark wireshark-dev wireshark-common -y

sudo apt autoremove

]

Now we want Wireshark 3.6.x, so we should add the PPA for Bionic (Ubuntu 18.04):

https://launchpad.net/~wireshark-dev/+archive/ubuntu/stable/

sudo add-apt-repository 'deb https://ppa.launchpadcontent.net/wireshark-dev/stable/ubuntu bionic main'

sudo add-apt-repository 'deb-src https://ppa.launchpadcontent.net/wireshark-dev/stable/ubuntu bionic main'

sudo apt update

sudo apt-get install wireshark wireshark-dev

We choose Yes when prompted for the non-root user approach to dumpcap.

sudo usermod -a -G wireshark $USER
sudo setcap cap_net_raw,cap_net_admin+eip /usr/bin/dumpcap

Reboot machine to make sure all the new config gets picked up.

sudo apt install git
git clone https://github.com/SecureAuthCorp/SAP-Dissection-plug-in-for-Wireshark/
cd SAP-Dissection-plug-in-for-Wireshark/
mkdir build
cd build
sudo apt install cmake
sudo apt install build-essential
cmake ..
make

At first I thought "och naw, ended in errors", but actually it built the SAP Dissectors plugin:

[100%] Linking CXX shared module sap.so

[100%] Built target sap

On the other hand it gives a load of warnings when dealing with vpa108csulzh.cpp, whatever that is:

/home/marmot/SAP-Dissection-plug-in-for-Wireshark/src/vpa108csulzh.cpp:443:16: warning: ISO C++17 does not allow ‚Äòregister‚Äô storage class specifier [-Wregister]

  443 |   REGISTER int bitcount;

      |                ^~~~~~~~

Aha, it's related to the LZH decompression algorithm used by SAPDIAG etc:

https://www.coresecurity.com/core-labs/advisories/sap-lzc-lzh-compression-multiple-vulnerabilities#:~:text=The%20following%20piece%20of%20code%20shows%20the,vpa108csulzh.cpp%20in%20the%20MaxDB%20source%20code%20%5B12%5D.

Possibly this warning can be removed by removing the word "REGISTER" from the source code, though didn't bother trying this. Instead we anyway continue the installation workflow:

make install

/home/marmot/.local/lib/wireshark/plugins/3.6/epan/sap.so

Now we can open Wireshark and the SAP Dissectors should work fine:

entry.title: SAP Integration Suite - Process Pallete Function
entry.content:
Process Palette Function

Process Pallete Function has three types:

  1. Integration Process
  2. Exception Sub Process
  3. Local Integration Process

 

Integration Process:

  • Act as a main workflow container for iFlows.
  • In integration process we can can perform the custom iFlow job.
  • Enables orchestration of different steps like content modification, transformation, and routing.

 

Exception Sub Process:

  • Handles errors in the Integration Process.
  • Starts with an Error Start Event.
  • Useful for logging, alerts, or fallback steps.

If any error occurs in integration process we can perform exception sub process (error handling). Exception Subprocess starts with Error Start Event. 

 

Local Integration Process:

  • A reusable mini process within the iFlow.
  • Called using Process Call.
  • Helps avoid repeating the same logic in multiple places.

We can perform whole integration process by single process call function by using Local Integration Process.

 

SAP Integration Suite  #IntegrationFlow #ExceptionSubProcess #LocalIntegrationProcess

entry.title: Re: Manage multiple add on fields under one sales order i...
entry.content:
Good day @ChinYeeChia 

Thank you for your question.

You can consult the following references for further details.

Manage Sales Orders, Manage Sales Order In, Secure Extensibility, Key User Extensibility

Feature Comparison for Creating, Changing, and Displaying Sales Orders with APIs.

To summarise, the public cloud does not permit you to extend Sales Order Item table directly to support your goal of one-to-many lot number relationships. Instead, you can use a Custom Business Object to store the lot details and link them to the Sales Order Item through associations. That will not require you modifying the clean-core structure designed for the Sales Order item. You can achieve this by:

  • Creating a CBO with fields for Sales Order, Item, Lot Number and Quantity.
  • Exposing it through the Custom Fields and Logic app to display or edit lots directly from the version 2 of the Manage Sales Orders.
  • You can as an option implement a Custom Logic BAdI to ensure total lot quantities match the item quantity.

Here is guidance for the system.

Search for Custom Business Objects. Create as shown on screen.

Add fields and enable UI Generation and OData Exposure.

Publish and confirm generated service (Test name used on this screen)

Open Custom Fields and Logic, add association field to SalesOrderItem. Use UI Adaption mode in Manage Sales Orders version 2 to add a new section or table showing the linked lots from the CBO

Finally, as an option, you can add Custom Logic BAdI to validate total quantities.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Reimagining Certification for the Way We Work Today
entry.content:
Hi Diana,

I appreciate the innovative approach SAP has introduced with the new certification model.

However, I have observed that there is currently no standardized mock test format available for candidates to practice before attempting the actual exam. Understanding the structure and flow of the assessment is crucial for effective preparation and confidence building.

entry.title: Re: Consignment Stock in SAP Business One
entry.content:
Hi, 

This is an important process that could be addressed in SAP Business One out of the box.  I can't see any added functionality offered here,  either than flagging a warehouse as "consignment warehouse" and assigning a BP to it.  Consignment processes are very different depending on where you sit  in the consignment process: Are you a Consignor or a Consignee? 

As a consignor: you transfer your stock to a third party to sell. The third party becomes liable to pay for your stock only once they sold it to their end-customer, or consumed it.  It makes sense to move consigned stock to a different B1 warehouse as stock is physically not on your premises anymore.  Stock withdrawals can be issued from that virtual warehouse with SAP Business One AR invoices based on report from the consignee's stock withdrawal (typically, Self Billing reports).  This is relatively straight forward to put in place but the process is not dedicated in B1 .

As a consignee (other side!):  you receive stock transferred from a supplier in your warehouse, for you to sell.

You don't own the stock, but you aim to sell it. It's in your catalogues, your pricelists, you bin locations etc: it should be treated as yours from an operational perspective and managed the same way you manage your own stock.  The justification for keeping  consigned stock in a separate warehouse is typically that it's value should not appear on the balance sheet. There is no operational value in managing the consigned stock in a separate (virtual) warehouse when you are the consignee. The balance sheet entries can be managed with advanced GL determination, managing determination at item level rather than warehouse level. As  a consignee, I'd managed the consigned stock alongside my own stock.  The complex part of the process for a consignee is the ability to issue AP self-billing to their suppliers. This feature does not exist in SAP Business One.   Self Billing consists, for a consignee, of reporting their stock withdrawals to their consignor and raising AP invoices accordingly to their Supplier (who will, as a consignor, raise their own AR invoices, as above).    

Improvement request can be upvoted here:  Improvement Request Details - Customer Influence

entry.title: Re: Linking Custom CDS View to Custom Field in SAP S/4HAN...
entry.content:
Hello @abinithim 

Thank you for your question.

You can consult the following references for further details.

Extensibility, Custom CDS Views, Custom Fields and Logic, Creating Custom Fields and Custom Business Logic & Bank Account

In summary, Custom CDS Views cannot directly consume Custom Fields in public cloud unless the underlying released interface view already includes them. The view I_BankAccountDEX you based on is a data extraction view and does not support extensibility through the Custom Fields framework. For you to expose your custom field together with the bank account data and stick with the public cloud clean-core approach, you can:

  • Base your CDS View on the extendable view I_BANKACCOUNTTP, which is aligned with your business context.
  • Alternatively, crate a composite CDS View that joins I_BankAccountDEX with I_BANKACCOUNTTP to bring in your custom field. Do this through the BankAccounID.

 

Below you will find a system guidance.

Go to Custom Fields. Open your Custom Field for I_BANKAACOUNTTP. (Screenshots acts as illustration)

In the UI and reports tab, check if it is enabled for Bank Account Master Data App and Associated CDS views.

Publish the field again. This ensures the field becomes part of I_BANKAACOUNTTP and any released views that consume it.

Next is to create a new Custom CDS View. The Bae View should be I_BANKAACOUNTTP, select both standard and your custom field and publish this new view. This ensures your CDS view inherits the extended field because it uses the same business context layer that was extended.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Help future-proof your database landscape with SAP HANA Cloud
entry.content:
Teched 2025 in Berlin. It was truly a great event and great experience meeting many of you in person, SAP colleagues, SAP customers, SAP partners and all the people who attended it and all those who are interested in technology and SAP solutions. 

I had a pleasure to attend this event together with SAP HANA Cloud database team and deliver the

Help future-proof your database landscape with SAP HANA Cloud deep-dive session. Those of you who attended the session have seen how SAP HANA Cloud may become a solid data foundation for your modern business critical applications. Let us have a brief look at the highlights one more time.

SAP HANA Cloud Database as a Service

First and foremost, SAP HANA Cloud is a database as a service (DBaaS). In contrast to database systems deployed in on-premise fashion, SAP HANA Cloud offers pleasant experience, allowing to focus on the core task - application development. 

In traditional on-premise scenario there is a unquestionable need to take care of hardware maintenance and renewal cycles, on top of this there is an operating system and database maintenance that all have to be done to ensure that the system is functioning. SAP HANA Cloud is a service, it releases users from these complex and time-consuming tasks. The powerful cockpit provides information on the state of the system, users may observe and apply patches and upgrades there. The rest is managed and users become released from the maintenance tasks, having their focus kept on the application development. Refer to the operating model for SAP HANA Cloud.

 

Data tiering

SAP HANA Cloud promotes efficient data tiering options. The most critical data can be stored in memory ensuring very fast access. Important, but less frequently accessed data might be stored on disk. This is possible thanks to SAP HANA Native Storage Extension (NSE) technology. The data offloaded on disk can be accessed seamlessly without a need for writing additional SQL queries for disk and in-memory access with NSE. There are also various large data processing and archiving options - SAP HANA Data Lake Relational Engine, which allows to store petabyte scale data and access it using relational format. On top of that SAP HANA Cloud offers SAP HANA Data Lake Files - a cost efficient object store allowing to work with unstructured, semi-structured and structured data, supporting CSV, Parquet and Delta Lake formats.

 

Elastic Compute Node

Recently SAP HANA Cloud introduced Elastic Compute Node (ECN). Imagine repetitive business critical process such as quarterly report that put your database system under high load. This event occurs only few times in specific period. Oftentimes your solution would be adding (purchasing) new or extra hardware components to meet demands. But what happens for the rest of the time? This hardware remains idle, because it is active only at the quarter end, to run the report. SAP HANA Cloud allows to provision elastic compute nodes to address these on-demand needs. Once the process is completed and there is no need for additional capacity, the elastic compute nodes can be deprovisioned. And this could be managed both via SAP HANA Cloud central (UI) -  database administration tool and via API, giving the users even more flexibility.

SAP HANA Cloud - database for Business AI

SAP HANA Cloud offers various AI options to its users. It helps building AI applications utilizing knowledge graph and vector engines. It offers AI co-pilots ensuring efficient application development. In addition to this there is AI for database operations for improved automation and AI-driven insights and AI for database administrators for easier database administration thanks to conversational interfaces.

The recent addition to the SAP HANA Cloud multimodel - knowledge graph allows to derive more business context from data. While large language model interprets natural language, the knowledge graph engine adds meaning to the data. In such AI scenario various SAP HANA Cloud multi model engines (vector, spatial, text search) could be combined to ensure insightful results. The knowledge graph might be used in RAG scenarios (Retrieval Augmented Generation) where it provides context to LLMs (Large Language Model).   

SAP HANA Cloud Migration

For those who are currently running SAP HANA database on-premise, or SAP HANA as a Service (Cloud Foundry or Neo platform) and are willing to make most of the innovations with SAP HANA Cloud, there is a way to transition.

Whether you use SAP HANA as a traditional database for your custom application, or you are using full capabilities of SAP HANA Extended Service Classic or Advanced (XSC, XSA) you can migrate these and there are various options available.

SAP HANA Cloud Self-Service Migration tool

This service can be found in the SAP HANA Cloud Cockpit, and is accessible as long as you have access to SAP HANA Cloud or SAP HANA Cloud central. This service is used to migrate SAP HANA database components (SQL layer) such as tables, views, procedures and data records. It also provides downtime-optimized migration method, to keep business-critical activities running during migration. The tool migrates SAP HANA XSA service instances, which is relevant for those who have XSA-managed schemas or HDI containers. These instances will be automatically created by the Self-Service in SAP HANA Cloud Cloud Foundry space if required.

 

SAP HANA Application Migration Assistant

The SAP HANA Application Migration Assistant is an extension for the SAP BTP Business Application Studio. It allows to migrate so-called design-time artefacts (Calculation Views, CDS Views, etc) to SAP HANA Cloud CAP (Cloud Application Programming Model) or SAP HANA Cloud Native. The tool requires Business Application Studio subscription and SAP HANA version 2.0. Various supported migration scenarios displayed on the image below:

 

Both the SAP HANA Cloud Self-Service migration tool and SAP HANA Application Migration Assistant provide extensive SAP HANA migration coverage allowing to migrate SAP HANA XS applications, SAP HANA database objects and data records stored in SAP HANA databases.

Migration Services

  • Migration help desk provides technical support for any questions related only to database migrations executed with the migration self service tool for SAP HANA Cloud migrationhelpdesk@sap.com
  • SAP HANA Database Migration Factory provides a high-touch expert support for SAP HANA Cloud migrations offering free migration assessments. Fixed bid, including migration project plan from architecture planning, optimization, migration, and testing to go-live migrationfactory@sap.com
  • SAP MaxAttention Program - limited to certain customers with SAP MaxAttention program contracts. The program offers support for the migration journey from database strategy and assessments to post go-live health check.

 

Useful Links

Official Migration Product Page

SAP HANA Cloud Migration Guide

Key SAP HANA Migration topics

entry.title: How to check the Tax Determination Logic and Tax Events for sales orders.
entry.content:
We would like to how the Tax Country/Region and Tax Code determined by the system for sales orders. 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to check the Tax Determination Logic and Tax Even...
entry.content:
Dear Customer, 

The automatic tax determination is based on many factors like:

  1. Ship-from country.
  2. Ship-to country.
  3. Type of the product (Material or Service).
  4. Tax Jurisdiction Code of the buyer.
  5. VAT registration of seller and buyer.
  6. Tax exemptions
  7. Legal Tax laws of the sender and receiver country.

If the involved parties are from different countries then system will check tax decision tree for each countries and then determine the tax details. 
Also if the External tax event determination (configuration solution) is active, then system will check the determination rule maintained. 

 

You can check the tax determination logic by following the below steps. 

The below steps apply to all sales documents, we are using a sales order as an example:

  1. Go to the work center view Sales Orders.
  2. Search for the relevant sales order.
  3. Click Edit and View All.
  4. Navigate to the Pricing and Invoicing tab.
  5. Click Update Pricing and select Activate Tax Trace.
  6. Click Save.

Now you have activated the tax trace for this sales order.

  1. Navigate to the Items tab and select the Taxes subtab.
  2. Click Display at Tax Trace Details.
  3. The Application Log opens. 
  4. Navigate to the Results tab.

You can review the logic applied to each sales order to gain insights into how the tax decisions were determined. Please note that these tax decisions are made in accordance with the specific tax policies of each country.

Best Regards, 

Arjun T H 

SAP Product Support
